In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  A key aspect of strong, sustainable, and inclusive growth is assuring adequate and 
quality employment, for which a strong skill base is required. In response, policy makers in 
developed and developing countries are prioritizing education, lifelong learning, job training, and 
skills development linked to growth strategies. Strong links are needed between the world of 
work and training providers to match skills development with employment. Policy makers are 
acknowledging the importance of anticipating and building capacity for future needs.1  
 
2.  A  number  of  Asian  countries  have  reached  middle-income  status.  Improving 
competitiveness to escape the “middle-income trap” entails strengthening skills that embody 
new technologies and innovation.2 However, the adoption of green growth policies is likely to 
require additional skills to succeed in the labor market. Several governments are building solid 
policy foundations toward green growth and need to prepare for the growth of green jobs 
through responsive education and training strategies.3  
 
3.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) Education Sector Operations Plan4 seeks to align 
ADB support in education with the needs and priorities of its developing member countries 
(DMCs)  and  strengthen  quality,  inclusiveness,  and  relevance  of  education.  The  plan 
emphasizes that ADB will support DMCs to diversify and expand higher education and technical 
and vocational education and training to match labor market needs and increase employment.   
In the backdrop of structural transformation spurred by a number of interrelated issues, the 
technical assistance (TA) will address the importance of dynamic skills development systems for 
middle-income economies and for a “greening” Asia. The TA was discussed at the South Asia 
Department  consultation  mission  in  India  in  April  2011  and  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development  Department  mission  to  Indonesia  in  June  2011.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.   
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Growth  rebounded  robustly  in  Asia  after  the  global  financial  crisis—economies 
recovered faster than expected. However, to maintain these growth rates, important concerns 
include increasing employment, facilitating technology absorption for global competitiveness, 
and curbing rising inequality. A key factor affecting rising inequality is rapid globalization, which 
raises skill premiums.5 Economies need to deepen skills to serve knowledge-based industries, 
provide  high  skills  to  support  technology  absorption  and  further  innovation,  and  broaden 
opportunities  for  skills  development  in  new  and  emerging  technology  areas.  Enhancing 
opportunities for skills training, particularly for poor and middle-income groups, women, and 
disadvantaged students in line with the needs of fast-growing industries, will bring employment 
benefits and higher incomes and act as an important contributor to inclusive growth. Youth 
unemployment and underemployment and obsolete skills are urgent issues to be addressed.  
                                                 
1 International Labour Organization. 2010. A Skilled Workforce for Strong, Sustainable and Balanced Growth–A G20 
Training Strategy. Geneva. 
2 Analysts have described “middle-income trap” as one where developing economies are not able to move beyond 
growth based on low-cost labor advantages in manufacturing for exports to growth that is capital and skill intensive, 
supports expanding domestic markets and the services sector, and brings greater value addition. 
3  ADB. Forthcoming. Green Growth, Resources and Resilience. Manila.  
4  ADB. 2010. Education by 2020: A Sector Operations Plan. Manila. 
5 World Bank. 2010. Securing the Present, Shaping the Future. East Asia and Pacific Economic Outlook. Vol. 1. 
Washington, DC.

2 
 
 
5.  Sustaining economic growth without compromising the environment is a policy challenge 
that Asia has begun to address. Awareness is increasing that green growth approaches are 
economically and politically feasible and profitable. A number of studies estimate that by 2030 
100 million green jobs6 will be available worldwide7—about 2% of the global workforce. Of 
these, 50 million green jobs are anticipated in Asia. Green stimulus packages after the financial 
crisis led to increased public investment in green infrastructure—public transport, low-carbon 
energy production, smart electricity grids, energy efficiency of public buildings, and water and 
sanitation infrastructure—including extensive employment opportunities.8 These include workers 
manufacturing fuel-efficient cars, solar panel technicians, green-building construction workers, 
renewable energy factory workers, and green professionals such as energy auditors. Previously 
attributed to eco-sectors, green jobs now include jobs in industries with greening potential.  
 
6.  Investment in the green economy will be good for the environment and for business; it 
will help position Asia for sustained rapid growth.9  If done correctly, moving to a low carbon 
world is expected to realize three significant benefits: reduced emissions, higher productivity of 
the economy, and inclusive growth. Green jobs have great potential, however, they do not need 
to  automatically  be  quality  jobs,  constituting  decent  work,  i.e.,  with  adequate  wages,  safe 
working conditions, job security, career prospects, and worker rights. The danger of “green 
washing” where only nominal support to environmental goals actually provides very poor quality 
employment is real. An example could be poor-quality recycling of electronics, which may give 
rise to employment in hazardous conditions. The use of unskilled labor in biofuel and biomass 
production  may  give  rise  to  numerous  jobs  but  at  subsistence  wages  and  poor  working 
conditions. In this case, green jobs do not constitute quality employment. Thus ensuring that 
green jobs are also “decent” jobs in pursuit of inclusive growth is important. For example, 
providing energy access to rural India and a distributed model of generating jobs that are not 
urban centric will support inclusive growth.   
 
7.  Education and training systems10 need to meet the needs of labor markets including 
those of green jobs. Enterprise surveys by the World Bank since 2000 reveal that 50% of firms 
surveyed in East Asia, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific are concerned with inadequate worker 
education  and  skills,  compared  with  25%  of  firms  surveyed  in  member  countries  of  the 
Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development.11 The survey found unemployment 
of graduates and fairly long time intervals to fill professional vacancies. These are symptomatic 
of education and training systems not being in step with skills needs of high growth sectors. 
Skills training initiatives need to be supplemented with effective skills forecasting models that 
are  responsive  to  industry  plans  and  requirements.  Responses  to  such  a  “crisis  of 
competencies” by the private sector has led to the creation of interesting new skill models. 
                                                 
6  Green jobs contribute to preserving or restoring the quality of the environment and can be in diverse sectors such 
as energy supply, recycling,  agriculture, construction, and transportation. They reduce the environmental footprint 
of economic activity and help cut consumption of energy, raw materials, and water through high-efficiency 
strategies to decarbonize the economy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, to minimize or avoid altogether all 
forms of waste and pollution, and to protect and restore ecosystems and biodiversity (United Nations Environment 
Programme). 
7  International Labour Organization. 2008. Skills for Improved Productivity, Employment Growth and Development. 
Report for the International Labour Conference, 97th session. Geneva, Switzerland. 
8 V. Anbumozhi, and A. Bauer. 2010. Impact of Global Recession on Sustainable Development and Poverty 
Linkages. ADBI Working Paper. No. 227. Tokyo: Asian Development Bank Institute. 
9  World Bank. 2010. Robust Growth, Rising Risks. East Asia and Pacific Economic Outlook. Vol. 2. Washington, DC. 
10 Throughout this paper, “education and training” refers to postsecondary, technical and vocational education and 
training, and higher education that contribute to skills development, and not basic education. 
11 World Bank. 2010. Stepping up Skills: For More Jobs and Higher Productivity. Washington, DC.

3 
 
 
8.  Countries are evaluating the costs of adopting green growth measures and industries 
are being encouraged to move to green production systems through incentives or regulatory 
requirements. Training is required in new and redefined skills to prepare the workforce for a 
green economy. New green jobs will become available and job substitution will result from the 
greening of corporations and the shift from fossil fuels to renewable sources.12 Education and 
training institutions do not yet have effective response strategies for green jobs. Training course 
offerings for green skills need to be developed in sectors that are key drivers of growth and high 
employment such as building and construction, transport, waste management, energy, and 
hospitality.  Green  industries  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  are  currently  fragmented.  University 
offerings  lack  cross-disciplinary  breadth  and  faculty  to  train  future  workers  in  technical, 
economic, social, and managerial challenges in green industry.  
 
9.  Industry and business have initiated steps to train workers for green processes and 
products;  however,  governments,  industries,  and  educational  institutions  have  not  yet 
developed coordinated actions to prepare the workforce in middle and higher green skills. As 
countries in Asia and the Pacific put in place national policies and strategies for climate change 
adaptation, mitigation, and green growth, the capacities needed have not been adequately 
analyzed. Furthermore, developing countries have not had sufficient coordination and dialogue 
on harmonizing skill standards for green occupations. Regional entities, such as the Association 
of Southeast Asian Nations, are supportive of bringing together business leaders in green 
industries to network. International commitment to clean and green growth are requiring a new 
cadre of green professionals in fields like assessment, reporting, and certification. Currently they 
are primarily from developed countries; developing countries in Asia have not yet developed a 
professional skills base. Knowledge sharing and exposure to how western countries developed 
these green certification professional cadres are insufficient. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact will be improved and increased availability of job-oriented courses and skills 
training, including for green occupations. By 2017, the number of courses and training curricula 
in skills including for green occupations will be improved and increased in four countries. The 
outcome will be increased knowledge and capacity of four DMCs in matching education and 
skills training to jobs, including for green occupations. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will help the DMCs put in place timely and effective policies and strategies for 
skills development, including for green growth. It will facilitate dialogue and networking between 
the public sector, business and sector councils, industry and occupational associations, and 
employee associations to assess gaps in policy and practice for the development of skills and to 
anticipate future needs. The TA will address both technology-oriented high-end skills as well as 
middle and lower-end skills to ensure that issues of inclusiveness are addressed in the context 
of rapidly growing economic sectors, including greening sectors.  
 
                                                 
12 United Nations Environment Programme. 2008. Green Jobs: Towards Decent Work in a Sustainable Low Carbon 
World. Nairobi, Kenya.

4 
 
12.  The TA will lead to improved knowledge and enhanced capacity in the DMCs to create 
an  adequate  skills  base  to  support  growth  and  employment  and  serve  green  jobs  in  key 
industries. Education and training institutions will become aware of best practices for curricula 
and  training  approaches  to  respond  to  skill  needs  in  key  industries.  The  TA  will  address 
industries  with  potential  for  high  employment,  growth,  and  greening  (e.g.,  building  and 
construction, transport, waste management, energy, and hospitality).   
 
13.  Four countries from among India, Indonesia, Sri Lanka, Uzbekistan, and Viet Nam will be 
selected for this TA, subject to the agreement of the respective governments. Appropriate skills 
for middle-income economies and strategies for increasing competitiveness are relevant to 
these countries, which  have initiated green economy initiatives. In Southeast Asia, Indonesia 
and Viet Nam have made considerable progress in education and can further strengthen skills 
development to meet labor market needs. In South Asia, India and Sri Lanka give high priority to 
skills development and employability. Uzbekistan is giving importance to skills and job creation 
in its economic stimulus initiatives.  While a common methodology and approach will be used 
for the four countries, the in-depth country reports will respond to the specific context of each 
country and take into account economic growth, structural transformation, and transition to 
green economy policy priorities articulated by the countries.  
 
14.  Output 1. An analysis of labor market needs, skills mismatch, and demand for skills for 
jobs, including green occupations, in selected industries will be completed for the four countries. 
Four country reports outlining opportunities for strengthening skills training systems to increase 
jobs  for  men  and  women  will  be  disseminated  and  discussed  with  government  and  other 
stakeholders by the end of 2013.  
 
15.  Output  2.  Lessons  from  global  best  practices  of  skills  development  systems  in 
industry-specific environments will be documented. Two case studies on improving employment 
for men and women through appropriate skills formation will be presented and discussed with 
the four countries by 2013. Four country workshops including one with regional participation, will 
address major reform areas for skills development, including skills for green jobs held.   
 
16.  Output 3. Recommendations will be prepared in each of the four countries for policy and 
strategy options for skills development for jobs for men and women, including green jobs. Four 
policy briefs will be prepared in consultation with business and industry and discussed by 2013. 
Two of the four country workshops held with interministerial collaboration, and exchange of 
experiences and knowledge will be undertaken (2012, 2013). 
 
17.  Output 4.  Recommendations will be prepared for the four countries on strengthening 
the participation of women and disadvantaged youth in skills training for improved job prospects, 
including in green occupations. Guidance notes on measures to increase the share of women 
and disadvantaged youth in skills training in high growth sector occupations including green jobs 
will be prepared for the four countries by 2013.    
 
18.  While the TA will support the DMCs in improving skills development strategies, it will 
also inform ADB operations in this area. The TA will help ADB operations departments identify 
new business opportunities for innovative skills development projects with the DMCs. The TA 
outputs will result in a major publication that combines four in-depth country studies, review of 
international best practices, proposals for next practices in the DMCs, and a clear articulation of 
policy options that could be applicable to other countries.

5 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $950,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The TA will be implemented over 30 months from October 2011 to April 2014. ADB will 
be the executing agency and the Poverty Reduction, Gender and Social Development Division 
of the Regional and Sustainable Development Department will lead TA implementation and 
administration. The TA will finance the services of a consulting team selected through a firm to 
provide 18 person-months of international and 48 person-months of national consulting. An 
experienced international expert on skills and workforce development with experience in green 
jobs will lead the team. Other inputs include support for country analysis, compilation of case 
studies, workshops, conferences, and travel. ADB will engage all consultants in accordance with 
the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).   
 
21.  The  Government  of  the  Republic  of  Korea  (Ministry  of  Strategy  and  Finance)  is 
considering parallel financing of about $300,00014 through Korea Eximbank (KEXIM); this will be 
confirmed after TA approval. Close coordination will be ensured between ADB and KEXIM. 
Active  consultations  will  be  undertaken  with  representatives  of  the  International  Labour 
Organization engaged in the topics of skills, employment, and green jobs. Other agencies such 
as the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, United Nations Environment 
Programme,  and  World  Bank  will  be  consulted  and  invited  to  appropriate  events.  Such 
international organizations will be knowledge partners of ADB by participating in events, and 
sharing information and data.   
 
22.  Institutions and government representatives from participating DMCs will be substantial 
stakeholders in TA implementation. They will be consulted during detailed country work and be 
invited  to  national  and  regional  workshops  and  conferences.  The  TA  team  will  facilitate 
participation from business and industry associations, private sector training entities, and other 
relevant institutions as appropriate during implementation. Vocational education and training 
system leaders, managers, and college directors will be consulted and invited to key workshops. 
Key agencies involved in documenting data on green jobs, education and skills training, and 
occupational standards will be consulted.  
 
  
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $950,000 on a grant basis for 
Education and Skills for Inclusive Growth and Green Jobs, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board. 
 
  
                                                 
14 The activities likely to be supported by KEXIM include an international skills forum, compilation of case studies from 
the Republic of Korea, support for study tours by DMC representatives to the Republic of Korea and industry 
linkages on skills development. These will be finalized and incorporated in a record of discussion between ADB 
and KEXIM after TA approval. The KEXIM contribution will be over and above the ADB financing; there will be no 
duplication of funding of activities or outputs.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  recruit  all  consultants  through  a  firm,  in 
accordance with the ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). The work assignment is for 2 years. 
 
A.  International Experts 
 
1.  Skills  Development  Specialist  and  Team  Leader  (international, 
8 person-months, intermittent) 
 
2.  The skills development specialist, the overall team leader of the technical assistance 
(TA) team, will have at least 15 years of experience, particularly in green growth, green jobs, 
and green skills; and have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Lead  the  work  of  the  team  with  substantive  technical  contributions,  and  be 
responsible for overall coherence and quality of the final outputs. 
(ii)  Provide guidance to other consultants. Be responsible for preparing work plans, 
inception report, progress reports, and the final TA report. Engage with other 
international agencies in coordinating and synergizing the work of the TA with 
ongoing work in the region on skills in general, and green skills in particular. Lead 
discussions with the developing member countries (DMCs) and facilitate ADB 
engagement with stakeholders on policies relating to education and skills for 
growth and green jobs. 
(iii)  Lead the research and study activities, and deliver a quality analytical report on 
new and innovative sector skill strategies to boost employment in middle-income 
economies and skills for green jobs in the four countries.  
(iv)  Plan and manage seminars, conferences, and policy roundtables in the DMCs on 
the preparation of case studies, policy briefs, and other knowledge products. 
(v)  Lead the development of policy options for the DMCs in the area of education 
and  training  response  to  emerging  priorities  for  growth  and  employment, 
including for green jobs, and prepare a synthesis study report. 
(vi)  Lead the analytical work for the preparation of key issues in training and skills 
development in the context of selected industries with potential for high growth, 
high employment, and greening. 
 
3.  Deliverables. These include an inception report, work plan, and budget within 3 weeks 
of the start of the assignment; quarterly progress reports to ADB; four synthesized country 
reports (Q1 2013); four policy briefs (Q2 2012); four guidance notes (Q2 2013); and workshop 
materials and workshop reports. 
 
2.  Technical  Education  and  Vocational  Training  Specialist  on  Green  Jobs 
(international, 5 person-months, intermittent) 
 
4.  The technical education and vocational training specialist will have extensive experience 
working in workforce skills development for employability in Asia, with familiarity and knowledge 
of issues of skills for green jobs. The specialist will work closely with education and training 
institutions to review plans and activities to strengthen the development of skills that meet the 
needs for growth, employment, and productivity increases. The specialist will have the following 
responsibilities:

Appendix 3  11 
 
(i)  Review and document gaps in integrating competencies and standards for skills 
in  the  selected  industries  in  TVET  institutions,  particularly  in  the  context  of 
contemporary concerns of increasing employment and productivity, and meeting 
the needs of greening corporations. Review how institutions are addressing the 
renewal of curricula in the context of growth dynamics of middle-income countries 
and  greening  economies.  Provide  an  assessment  of  how  skills  training 
institutions  can  effectively  develop  responsive  mechanisms  to  ensure  the 
maintenance of curriculum and the meeting market needs. 
(ii)  Assemble  country-specific  standards  (and  regional  standards,  if  any)  in  the 
specific industries of the study, including nascent green standards; and assess 
the readiness of educational institutions for effective skills formation.   
(iii)  Prepare and disseminate case studies of successful approaches to developing 
skills in the context of transforming industries and the emergence of new green 
industries. 
(iv)  Prepare an inventory of regulations, standards, and accreditation for skills in the 
sectors concerned, covering the spectrum of low, middle, and high-level skills. 
(v)  Undertake a review of policy of the countries with regard to skills development 
and develop country papers on an education and training response to growth, 
employment, and green economies. 
(vi)  Contribute as a resource person to workshops and seminars as required. 
 
5.  Deliverables. These include four  country reports on skills gap analysis (Q3 2012); four 
country reports on standards, regulations, and industry-recognized accreditation of qualifications 
(Q1 2013); one case study on successful implementation of skills development for green jobs 
(Q3 2012); and workshop materials and workshop reports. 
 
3.  Private Sector Skills Specialist (international, 5 person-months, intermittent) 
  
6.  The international private sector skills specialist will be familiar with working with skills 
with  regard  to  business  and  industry  needs,  private–public  partnerships  for  skills,  and 
private-sector-led initiatives to improve the quality of skills development for increasing jobs. The 
specialist will work closely with business, industry associations, and employer organizations in 
reviewing how skills mapping is done to meet industry needs, including for green skills. The 
specialist will have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Review and compile an inventory of key changes in skills profiles required in the 
selected industries, based on demand by companies and employers. 
(ii)  Assess how training organizations are responding to specific skills standards for 
low, medium, and high skill jobs, including green jobs as articulated by industry. 
(iii)  Provide an assessment of business and industry expectations and projected 
skills requirements for new occupations and jobs that are being transformed by 
greening of corporations.  
(iv)  Analyze and assess the adequacy of skills forecasting mechanisms and tools in 
effectively identifying industry demand in a timely fashion. 
(v)  Review and analyze ongoing and projected efforts for workplace-based training in 
the selected industries, and recommend how they may be integrated with formal 
training institutions.  
(vi)  Organize  and  document  policy  roundtables  involving  the  private  sector  and 
industry associations.

12  Appendix 3 
 
(vii)  Assist in building integral links between education and training institutions and 
private sector bodies to ensure that skills training is calibrated with the world of 
work for the present and future. 
(viii)  Contribute as a resource person to workshops and seminars as required. 
 
7.  Deliverables.  These  include  four  country  reports  on  industry  outlook  on  skills  in 
fast-growing industries (Q3 2012); four country reports on workplace-based training programs 
and  private  sector-based  skills  forecasting  tools  (Q1  2013);  a  case  study  on  successful 
partnership between private sector–industry and education and training institutions to implement 
skills development for green jobs (Q3 2012); and workshop materials and workshop reports. 
 
B.  National Experts and Researchers 
 
1.  Technical  Education  and  Vocational  Training  Specialists  (national, 
28 person-months; 7 person-months for each expert in four countries) 
 
8.  Each of the four countries participating in the TA will have a national technical education 
and vocational training specialist with knowledge of issues linking skills to growth, productivity, 
and employment, including green jobs. The experts will provide necessary guidance and inputs 
on national policies and priorities with regard to skills development strategies and initiatives. 
They will collaborate with international experts in dialogue with key stakeholders in government, 
business, and workers’ organizations. They will collaborate in the study; preparation of reports, 
case studies,  and seminar  papers;  and  contribute  as  resource  persons  to  workshops  and 
seminars as required. The specialists will work closely with the international technical education 
and vocational training specialist and the team leader in reviewing and assessing overall gaps 
and issues in forecasting skills requirements, the readiness of education and training institutions 
in meeting the demands of employers and companies, compiling standards and benchmarks for 
skills profiles in the industries concerned, and the links with private sector entities to better 
match supply with demand. 
 
9.  Deliverables. Each country expert will provide a country overview report on diagnostic 
data on skills and jobs, including green occupations (Q4 2012); country report on a review of 
existing  and  planned  initiatives  for  education  and  training  institutions  to  strengthen  links 
between skills development and job market needs and plans for courses and training programs 
for  green  skills  (Q2  2013);  a  country  review  of  standards,  accreditation  procedures,  and 
industry-led skills recognition methods, including existing and emerging standards for green 
skills in identified industries (Q1 2013); and workshop materials and workshop reports. 
 
2.  Market  Research  and  Survey  Specialists  (national,  12  person-months; 
 3 person-months for each expert in four countries) 
 
10.  Each of the four countries participating in the TA will have a national market research 
and/or survey specialist who will collect and compile data from training institutions, industry 
associations, and companies to support the analysis of latest trends in skills profiles, job market 
requirements, qualifications and skills standards, and new and emerging skills requirements in 
high-growth  industry  segments.  (This  may  include  funding  a  market  research  firm  for  a 
business-oriented survey). 
 
11.  Deliverables. Each country expert will deliver a compilation of secondary data on skills 
gaps and mismatch in education and training in the context of jobs in high-growth industry 
segments (Q2 and Q3 2012); a survey and compilation of data from the primary survey of

Appendix 3  13 
 
industry and training institutions on skills for high-growth industry segments, including green 
skills and qualifications (Q1 2013); a country review of standards, qualification frameworks, and 
certification processes for skills in key occupations in the selected industries (Q1 2013); and 
skills forecasting tools, deriving information from investment plans, industry movements, and 
employer needs (Q1 2013). 
 
3.  Gender  and  Social  Protection  Specialists  (national,  8  person-months;  
2 person-months for each expert in four countries) 
 
12.  Each of the four countries participating in the TA will have a national gender and social 
protection specialist who will help review and assess the needs of women and measures 
required to help them participate effectively in skills training and new occupations, including 
green occupations; review needs and measures required for retraining older workers, and 
life-long learning to ensure labor mobility and continued workforce participation; review issues 
faced by youth and vulnerable workers, including in small and medium-sized enterprises to 
claim a fair share of employment opportunities, including in new green occupations; provide 
inputs to document active labor market intermediation policies required by the countries for 
appropriate labor market response to increasing jobs; and contribute as a resource person to 
workshops and seminars as required. 
 
13.  Deliverables.  Each  country  expert  will  provide  a  country  review  report  of  social 
protection measures in the context of vocational education and training in green jobs (Q3 2012); 
a country analytical report on green job opportunities and decent employment (Q4 2012); a 
review of strategies and initiatives for ensuring the participation of women and youth in green 
occupations and jobs (Q1 2013); four guidance notes on increasing participation of women and 
disadvantaged youth in skills development for jobs in high-growth sectors and green jobs; and 
workshop materials and workshop reports.
